t: Job 40
Job: What Can I Say?
Then*p the Lord*s said to Job,
“Will*pn the faultfinder contend with the Almighty? Let*ln him who reproves God answer it.”
Then*p Job answered the Lord*s and said,
“Behold,*pn I am insignificant; what can I reply to You? I*ln lay my hand on my mouth.
Once*ln I have spoken, and I will not answer; Even*ln twice, and I will add nothing more.”
God Questions Job
Then*p the Lord*s answered Job out of the storm and said,
“Now*pn gird up your loins like a man; I*ln will ask you, and you instruct Me.
Will*ln you really annul My judgment? Will*ln you condemn Me that you may be justified?
Or*ln do you have an arm like God, And*ln can you thunder with a voice like His?
“Adorn*ln yourself with eminence and dignity, And*ln clothe yourself with honor and majesty.
Pour*ln out the overflowings of your anger, And*ln look on everyone who is proud, and make him low.
Look*ln on everyone who is proud, and*i humble him, And*ln tread down the wicked where they stand.
Hide*ln them in the dust together; Bind*ln them in the hidden place.*i
Then*ln I will also confess to you, That*ln your own right hand can save you.
God’s Power Shown in Creatures
“Behold*pn now, Behemoth, which I made as well as you; He*ln eats grass like an ox.
Behold*ln now, his strength in his loins And*ln his power in the muscles of his belly.
He*ln bends his tail like a cedar; The*ln sinews of his thighs are knit together.
His*ln bones are tubes of bronze; His*ln limbs are like bars of iron.
“He*ln is the first of the ways of God; Let*ln his maker bring near his sword.

Under*ln the lotus plants he lies down, In*ln the covert of the reeds and the marsh.

If*ln a river rages, he is not alarmed; He*ln is confident, though the Jordan rushes to his mouth.
